column2: EpicEditor is an embeddable JavaScript Markdown editor with split fullscreen editing, live previewing, automatic draft saving, offline support, and more. For developers, it offers a robust API, can be easily themed, and allows you to swap out the bundled Markdown parser with anything you throw at it.

Links in the form of twitter.com/[username]/profile_picture do work.

Added 'main' to point to build JS.

Resolves #387
--

When using NPM as the method to install EpicEditor, and then building the application (using WebPack for example), the main entry point JS file is not resolved.

Ie. These don't work.
```
var EpicEditor = require('epiceditor');
import EpicEditor from 'epiceditor';
```

The `package.json` is missing the `main` declaration that tells the builder which is the entrypoint file.

Remove `text-align:left` from github.css

Remove `text-align:left` from github.css

GFM has support for specifying alignment in tables by using colons in the header row (see https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown#tables). Currently github.css overrides this by forcing left alignment for no good reason.

Ticket #107 - Initial support for adding textarea support. This means if you include
the "textarea" option and select an element (or pass an ID as a string) it will sync
the textarea with what you see in the editor. This is useful for people who don't
want or need to use AJAX to submit a form. Instead, the textarea will have the exact
contents of the editor.

Ticket #178 - We don't want to replace all spaces with  
because the text will not wrap then (Non-Breaking SPace)

Fix for browsers that support innerText when the body of the
document doesn't have any content. This was causing problems where
the editor was acting totally different in some places (like JSBin)
and different on others (like epiceditor.com). The problem was that
we were checking for if(document.body.innerText) which would be
false if the body didn't have any text therefore it'd try to run
the else which is meant mainly for Firefox since it's the only
browser that doesn't support innerText. Now we check for typeof
innerText. If it returns any string, including "" then it'll
return true.

Added IE9 support which fixed #5,
Note: added a _isIE() function but it should not be used if possible. Where I used it to fix the height issue in preview mode is because I couldn't find where the 2px was coming from. All values of height, padding, offsetHeight, etc were exactly the same as Chrome and Firefox.
